4.67.text:
Well, thank you very much all of you for coming
out on what has proven to be quite a chilly day.

10.18.text:
I'm going to be talking to you this afternoon
about a campaign that took place

17.40.text:
I would like to start by asking a question.
How many of you are actually familiar with

24.38.text:
the Chindits? Does that name mean... and General
Wingate?

33.47.text:
Yes. His reputation goes before him after 70 years, 
doesn't it?

35.85.text:
OK. Well, I was very fortunate, first of all
because my father was a Chindit and he told

44.00.text:
me a little bit, but only a little bit, about
the campaign. But he wouldn't tell me very much,

49.52.text:
certainly not enough to write a book.
Instead I wrote a book about Bomber Command.

55.62.text: Sadly I lost him eight years ago.

60.24.text:
And after that, two or three years later,
I decided that I would write that book about

67.50.text:
the Chindits and this was the result, 
'War in the Wilderness'. And it was published in

73.25.text:
October 2011 by the History Press, and I was
doubly fortunate in that I was able to

90.07.text:
I was very lucky because I worked through
the Chindits Old Comrades Association and

96.97.text:
because of the Freedom of Information Act
they couldn't give me a list of their members.

104.22.text:
But I found a 1993 list of members in the
papers given to me by a Chindit veteran.

113.85.text:
So, I sent the list to the Chindits Old Comrades
Association and said, 'Can you tick those

120.20.text:
that it probably wouldn't be worth writing
to?' [Laughter] And apparently that complied

131.90.text:
with the Act's requirements and I managed to get 
in touch with the people and write this book.

139.98.text:
It took three years to write. It was very
complicated. I decided I would do two things:

145.72.text:
I would give a narrative of the two Chindit
campaigns, but my main objective was to record

153.39.text:
the 50 stories of the suffering that these
men underwent during the campaign. And I would,

163.04.text:
in effect, tell the definitive human story
of the Chindit experience, and I hope to share

169.82.text: some of that with you this afternoon.

172.00.text:
Of course, the Chindit concept came from Major
General Orde Wingate, quite a famous gentleman,

182.22.text:
not unique by any means in the annals of the
British Army. He was quite an eccentric and

192.38.text:
even today, 70 years on, as I have experienced
myself personally in my correspondence with

199.04.text:
a certain Gurkha officer, he is still very
much a figure of controversy.

206.07.text:
But we start with this badge. This is my father's
shoulder flash. It was worn on the right upper

215.10.text:
arm and it's the 'Chinthe'. It's the mythical...
I think they call them 'fabulous lions' that

224.61.text:
protect the pagodas in Burma. And this was
adopted as the Chindit symbol.

234.57.text:
And Wingate wanted this to be a badge of honour.
It was his view that any man who served as

242.82.text:
a Chindit should have the right, throughout
his army service, to continue to wear this flash.

248.14.text:
I don't actually believe that that
wish was fulfilled, but that, I understand,

254.90.text: was his intention. So, let's move on.

263.59.text:
There were two Chindit campaigns. The first
one was called Operation LONGCLOTH and it

269.21.text:
took place in 1943. It involved taking in
a brigade, around about 3,000 men, and it

276.31.text:
was led by Wingate personally. There were
to be eight columns, but by the time they

281.23.text:
were ready, having finished their arduous
training, there were only enough men left

285.59.text: for seven, and seven columns went in.

288.83.text:
There was a five-column force operating to
the north in Burma, and to the south of them

295.53.text:
as a diversionary force there were a further
two columns. Each column consisted of

305.46.text:
Let me introduce you to some of the members
of the wireless detachment of 21 Column,

312.01.text:
The Queen's Regiment. The man in front - this
is the wireless detachment - the man in front

317.40.text:
there is still alive. I spoke to him quite
recently, and his name is Tony Howard.

322.06.text:
He is quite ill today, but he's there leading
his detachment across a 'chaung', a Burmese river.

332.95.text:
Immediately behind him is George Hill, one
of his signallers, and George Hill is leading

340.24.text:
a mule called Taxi. Taxi has on either side
the large radio panniers.

349.03.text:
He has got the transmitter on one side and he 
has got batteries on the other.

352.91.text:
And Taxi was a very awkward mule. Apparently
he had a sense of humour. When it was time

359.84.text:
to be loaded in bivouac, they would put one
of the panniers on and Taxi would start to

367.75.text:
lean against it and somebody would come round
to try and straighten him up and Taxi would

375.06.text:
lean some more. And by the time he had got
three people trying to push him to bring him

379.88.text:
upright, he would give something that sounded very 
much like a laugh. So Taxi had a sense of humour.

388.38.text:
This picture was taken during the second expedition.
They are two days away from Aberdeen,

393.94.text:
which was the code name for the airstrip from 
which they will fly out. They walked in

401.09.text:
and they walked out to the airstrip where they were 
flown out, and they walked about a thousand miles.

409.90.text:
It was a standing joke in my family that my
dad... well two standing jokes.

415.65.text:
Firstly he used to say to me, 'You'd be no good 
in the jungle.' And I suspect he was right, OK.

421.24.text:
And the second thing was that he would always
get lost in later life and my mother used

426.66.text:
to get irritable and say, 'Well, I can't understand
it. You walked a thousand miles in the Burmese

431.49.text:
jungle and you can't find Tesco's.' [Laughter]
Anyway, there we are.

439.25.text:
A strange type of warfare - it was a mixture of 
mediaeval savagery in that you're in the jungle,

448.04.text:
the average visibility was about 10-20 yards [9-18m] 
and you could be ambushed at any time.

455.53.text:
I suspect a lot of the ambushes
were in fact British and Japanese soldiers

463.39.text:
simply bumping into each other. It felt like
an ambush at the time, if you get my drift.

470.42.text:
And so you had this mediaeval-type of warfare
because when you did clash it was likely to

477.71.text:
be hand-to-hand, close-quarters fighting where
you used anything you could lay your hands on -

482.40.text:
shovels, bayonets, machetes ('dhars'
as they were known), bayonets,

492.69.text:
anything you could lay your hands on, really, 
for immediate action.

496.67.text:
On the other hand, these campaigns, particularly
the second campaign, was very much the high spot

502.61.text:
of 1940s technology, because the only way these 
men could survive going behind Japanese lines,

510.59.text:
150-200 miles [241-322km], sometimes
further, was to have everything they needed

516.93.text:
air dropped to them. And you can't do that
without aircraft. And you can't do it, certainly,

521.96.text:
without the wireless - and it was absolutely
essential that you had the wireless communication.

528.51.text:
So, a strange mix of high technology and the
mediaeval.

535.87.text:
You probably can't see a lot of detail in
the back of the room, in fact I'm sure you can't,

539.77.text:
but this is a picture, a map, of India on the left, 
China on the right, Burma in the centre.

546.98.text:
The grain of the country goes
north to south, the hills, the so-called hills,

555.73.text:
the Naga Hills and other series of hills in
northern Burma are up to 8,000 feet high and

563.47.text:
you go up one hill and then you go down the
other. There's a river at the bottom to cross,

568.78.text:
then you go up again. And it wasn't unknown
for one column, half of one column, to be

574.70.text:
on top of one hill and the other half to be
on top of the other when they camped for the night.

581.51.text:
So the country is unbelievably difficult.
To give you some idea of the conditions,

588.88.text:
you're talking about temperatures of 
110-112 degrees [44C], ultra-high humidity.

599.29.text:
In the monsoon season, obviously, it's raining all 
the time and you are soaking wet, so your kit starts

604.74.text:
to rot on you and you develop all sorts of
jungle sores and other nasty complaints.

613.76.text:
What would you imagine would be the most serious
threat to health in these circumstances?

622.29.text:
Well somebody said dysentery in the front here...
malaria. Malaria was the major challenge but

629.08.text:
also dysentery, general debility, jungle sores
and perhaps...

637.41.text:
Yes, I think you are right there. Dehydration.
You can go without food for a very long period

645.93.text:
of time. You can see from my appearance that
I've never been hungry. [Laughter] And I suspect

652.57.text:
probably that a lot of you have never been
hungry, truly hungry. But I understand that

658.86.text:
you can carry on for many, many days without
food. But in the Burmese jungle after some

665.27.text:
time during the course of the third day, your
spirit will break and you will die of dehydration

671.66.text:
if you haven't had water. So water is absolutely
crucial. And as for the diseases, malaria

677.45.text:
was prevalent, but the most feared disease,
probably, was tick typhus.

687.70.text: And that made short work of many a Chindit.

692.88.text:
And many of them ended up in jungle graves,
a simple grave, and a map reference and other

703.75.text:
geographic points of navigation were taken
every time something like this occurred. And

711.60.text:
in the following seven or eight months after
the second campaign volunteers followed all

716.58.text:
those jungle tracks and recovered as many
remains as they possibly could. A really determined

723.04.text:
effort was put in to recover the men who were
left in Burma. And many, of course, are still in Burma.

731.48.text:
Well, this is General Wingate. My dad remembered
him. My dad was a private solider.

738.27.text:
He was a Bren gunner in the 2nd Battalion, The King's
Own Royal Regiment. I asked him whether he

743.91.text:
was in 41 Column or 46 and he told me, 'Does
it really matter now?' And that's very difficult

750.54.text:
to answer, unless you have an idea of writing
a book at some point.

754.85.text:
Anyway, he was eventually in 41 Column because
like so many other Chindit battalions they

761.02.text:
lost so many men that in the end they formed
a composite column and the King's Own composite

766.28.text:
column was Column 41, so he was certainly
in there towards the end of it.

770.93.text:
He remembers Wingate coming on parade with
a pocketful of onions, which he munched rather

777.59.text:
like apples, and swore that you could carry
on forever if only you could lay your hands

782.86.text:
on sufficient onions. He was a true eccentric.
He was very fond of giving orders to his officers

790.76.text:
whilst completely naked. He also had a strange
habit of brushing his pubic hair with a toothbrush!

800.77.text:
According to Wilfred Thesiger, who served
with him in Abyssinia, it wasn't necessarily

805.36.text:
his toothbrush, which is very unfortunate!
[Laughter]

810.58.text:
I thought a lot about General Wingate and
I decided early on in writing the book that

815.12.text:
I wasn't going to join the clan who had written
books about him either to attack him and destroy

821.06.text:
his reputation or make him out to be some
sort of saint and huge military genius.

828.04.text:
As far as I'm concerned it was all contrived.
He realised that if you wanted to get on in

833.49.text:
the Army you had to have two things. First
of all you had to be successful -

838.71.text:
he was certainly successful, in his own way - 
and you also had to be unforgettable.

845.40.text:
And I think standing there doing that with a 
toothbrush in front of your officers

849.58.text: will probably make you quite unforgettable.

852.08.text:
He had some success in Abyssinia putting the
Emperor Haile Selassie back on the throne.

861.94.text:
He managed to fool 20,000 Italians and persuade
them to give up to a couple of thousand irregulars.

869.60.text:
And they were most amazed when they were disarmed
and saw who had actually taken them prisoner.

876.39.text:
And he had a way of ensuring that he was playing
to the crowd, let's say. And he rode the Emperor's

886.28.text:
white horse on the return to Addis Ababa,
mainly because the Emperor apparently didn't

891.97.text:
fancy riding him because he wasn't very good
on a horse and didn't want to fall off in

900.35.text:
This is Bernard Fergusson. He was a column commander 
in the first expedition, Operation LONGCLOTH.

905.24.text:
He was a brigade commander. He
was in charge of 16 Brigade that walked in.

917.84.text:
The only brigade to walk in in the second
expedition.

920.63.text:
He was quite a man. He wrote two wonderful
books, 'The Wild Green Earth' [1946] and

926.64.text:
'Beyond the Chindwin' [1945], and highly recommended.
They are wonderful accounts of the Chindit experience.

933.78.text:
He is often described as a bit
of a toff. Don't be fooled by this appearance.

941.78.text:
After the second expedition he is usually
there looking very spruce and wearing a monocle.

947.69.text:
He lived on and survived the two Chindit campaigns.
He became the master of Ballentrae and eventually

955.53.text: Governor of New Zealand, so quite a man.

962.47.text:
This is how the Chindits got their supplies.
There's a problem here. They survived on K rations.

969.03.text:
K rations were supposed to be emergency
rations for a limited period in a combat zone.

975.63.text:
You've got three packs a day - breakfast,
lunch and dinner. And they were about the

982.48.text:
size of an old-fashioned video tape and you
would be provisioned for five days,

988.77.text:
so you would have 15 packs each following an air
drop. But, of course, you had to

995.34.text: have a good air drop to get that supply.

998.06.text:
Typically those rations had to last eight
or nine days and basically the calorie deficit

1005.17.text:
was around about 1,200 calories a day. So
everybody who survived the Chindit campaign

1011.60.text:
lost at least 2 or 3 stone, but my dad lost
3 stone [19kg] - he went in at 10 stone [63kg]

1016.08.text:
and he came out at 7 [44kg]. But they offered
him the chance to be a driver or a cook after

1024.11.text:
he had recovered, so which do you think he
chose? [Laughter] Yes, my dad was no fool.

1030.97.text:
He cooked breakfast for a battalion for about
six months and ended up being very happy.

1038.42.text:
I don't know whether anybody can read those
letters there, but the first expedition the

1046.16.text:
only way they could get back - they were walking
back - the only way you could get back was

1051.64.text:
basically to break up into small dispersal
groups - the ideal size was round about 40 men -

1058.19.text:
and take your chances. You either walked
back to India or you went north-north-east

1064.63.text: towards China, but they were the two choices.

1068.41.text:
This lot decided to walk to China. They had
no petrol for their wireless, they had just

1075.93.text:
enough for one last transmission so they sent
a QQ. A QQ is a request for stores, a standard

1082.77.text:
store drop for a column, and they had 17 or
18 wounded and sick men with them who couldn't

1090.18.text:
go any further. So as the drop occurred they
took the white parachutes and rearranged them,

1097.88.text:
and those words are Plane Land Here Now, and
they did. Three days later a C47 Dakota came back

1110.65.text: and landed and took these men out.

1115.13.text:
The man standing is a corporal. He is suffering
from dysentery and he has got an infected hip.

1120.36.text:
If you look at the chap on the far right
there, I think his expression tells everything

1126.54.text:
you need to know, really, about the first
Chindit expedition. It was absolutely appalling.

1131.76.text: But these men were actually flown out.

1136.58.text:
They couldn't fly the rest out in the party
because it was only 20 miles [32km] away from

1141.58.text:
a Japanese fighter field, so they had to walk
to China, and they succeeded. And when they

1147.65.text:
reached China, the Americans flew them home
and Chiang Kai-shek treated them as heroes

1152.82.text:
and actually gave each of them a few hundred
dollars to buy presents for their wives and families.

1158.92.text:
So it is quite amazing how your fortunes can change 
if you have the good luck to reach safety.

1167.93.text:
This is the chap that is standing up and talking
to one of his colleagues. If you look at the

1172.48.text:
man on the left you will see his right arm,
he has taken a wound in the arm

1181.59.text: and you can see the state of the clothing.

1188.36.text:
This man is 23 years old and it tells you
something about the state of Chindit dentistry.

1195.66.text:
He's obviously delighted that he's getting
out. He's got a sweat rag around his neck

1201.58.text:
and that was actually called a 'panic map'
because on one side of the cloth was a map,

1210.68.text:
a screen-printed map of north Burma. And I've
seen four or five examples of Chindits who

1219.80.text:
had retained their panic maps. It's quite
interesting really because

1223.89.text: they are still sweat stained after 70 years.

1228.90.text:
Here are more men grateful to get out. 
If you look at the man on the right-hand side,

1235.58.text:
you will see the deep jungle sores on his arm, 
very glad to get out there with a Gurkha colleague.

1244.75.text:
And this man, well again, you can see the jungle sores 
on his right arm. He is holding up a spoon,

1248.81.text:
and the spoon is very important to him 
because it was a spoon they used to

1253.81.text:
divvy out the last remaining rice that they
bought in a Burmese village.

1260.25.text:
And that was the spoon that kept every man alive, 
so it's somebody's treasured possession right now.

1268.95.text:
And here is the man that brought them out.
He is Flying Officer Michael Vlasto.

1273.28.text:
He put his Dakota down in 700 yards [640m] of basically
paddy field and he stayed on the ground for 12 minutes,

1282.94.text:
kept the engine running, got them into 
the aircraft and even managed to take

1287.43.text: off again without incident. So he is a hero.

1294.13.text:
But it was different. In the second expedition
it was decided that it would be six or seven

1302.02.text:
times bigger than the first expedition. 
It would be called Operation THURSDAY.

1307.50.text:
That is because it was launched on a Sunday! [Laughter]
And the advance parties landed in gliders,

1318.95.text:
The glider assault team made night landings
at a place called Broadway. It was a jungle

1326.99.text:
clearing about 165 miles [265km] behind enemy
lines and they flew in at night in bright

1333.73.text:
moonlight conditions and they flew in with Waco gliders. 
Some of the gliders had portable bulldozers.

1340.97.text:
And the idea was that the advance
wave would go in, they would secure the boundary

1351.70.text:
of the clearing against Japanese intrusion
and start to prepare the clearing for the

1358.34.text:
landing of the main force by Dakota. 
So, four brigades would eventually fly in.

1369.85.text:
Later in my life I learnt to fly gliders and
I remember asking my father whether he would

1377.89.text:
like to come along one summer's afternoon for a trip. 
I can't possibly tell you how he replied,

1382.45.text:
but the essence of it was, 'I've done it once son,
and I've no intention of doing it again.'

1393.09.text:
In the first expedition if you couldn't march
you were left. They'd give you a spare clip,

1400.40.text:
probably another water bottle, maybe one or
two K rations or meal packs and leave you

1405.99.text:
there at the trackside and there it was. 
And the men obviously found it very, very hard.

1415.06.text:
Of the 3,000 men that went in on the first expedition 
2,000 came back, just over 2,000 came back,

1422.59.text:
and the rest were killed, wounded,
missing. Quite a lot of them were captured.

1428.28.text:
And one of the big problems from a morale
point of view was having to leave your comrades

1436.95.text:
at the side of the track, and knowing that
it's very unlikely that they will survive.

1444.86.text:
It was decided in the second expedition that
the Chindits... Wingate could talk the hind

1451.73.text:
legs off a mule, and he managed to persuade the 
Americans to provide him with a private air force.

1457.45.text:
But even he was astounded when
he saw exactly what they intended to provide -

1463.32.text:
fighters, bombers, gliders, transport aircraft and 
these small aircraft that were

1472.79.text:
used for casualty evacuation. And many a Chindit's
life was saved by small aircraft of this type.

1478.31.text:
Here is a picture of three likely lads. 
My father is in the middle, Jack Redding.

1489.53.text:
Dave Davis and another gentleman are with him.
My dad was the only survivor.

1497.63.text:
One died of cerebral malaria and the other one was 
killed in action, so they were a bit like

1503.67.text:
the Three Musketeers when they were training 
for the second Chindit operation.

1511.02.text:
During the second Chindit operation, the West
Africans provided a brigade and they were

1517.62.text:
extremely good soldiers in the jungle, much
feared by the Japanese. They did very, very well.

1523.04.text:
They were originally designated as garrison
troops for the strongholds that Wingate's

1530.42.text:
soldiers created behind enemy lines, from which 
they would sally forth to blow up railway bridges,

1536.54.text:
block roads and generally disrupt
Japanese communications. That was the purpose

1542.60.text:
of the Chindit campaigns, but they put in some 
very, very good fighting - excellent troops.

1553.40.text:
This is Bernard Fergusson again. This is Officers
Call in the jungle. The one thing you really

1558.94.text:
need to know at the end of a hard day's march
in the Burmese jungle is what happens if you

1564.18.text:
get ambushed or dispersed in some way. 
You need the 24-hour rendezvous reference.

1573.48.text:
So at Officers Call there were two rendezvous,
one was for 24 hours and one was for 72 hours,

1579.78.text:
so if you didn't make the 72 hours then you
were on your own. And that's basically the

1585.51.text:
most important information you needed at the
end of every day -

1590.43.text: what happens if we get bushwhacked during the night?

1593.42.text:
The conditions were appalling. Wingate decided
that the Chindits would stay in for a maximum

1603.07.text:
of three months. In fact in the second expedition
they stayed in for five months, including the monsoon.

1608.53.text:
The conditions were absolutely
appalling. And, of course, it became more

1613.66.text:
and more difficult, one to supply the troops
with enough food and ammunition, and also

1619.49.text:
it became incredibly difficult to physically
operate on the ground. And quite often in

1627.75.text:
going up very, very steep hillsides the mules...were
basically unloaded and the kit and stores

1639.22.text:
had to be manhauled up the slopes, it was
the only way of getting them up.

1645.93.text:
This is a map of the second expedition, Operation THURSDAY. 
My dad flew into Broadway with the advance troops.

1653.38.text:
Some of the brigades flew into Aberdeen, which 
was another airfield behind enemy lines.

1662.59.text:
It is not right, probably, to call it an airfield; 
it was simply a jungle clearing.

1668.01.text:
And there was also Chowringhee, which was used to fly in 
part of my dad's brigade, which was 111 Brigade.

1681.20.text:
So, here we are. It's Sunday, 5 March 1944
for Operation THURSDAY. And you can see the

1689.21.text:
gliders getting ready and the tow lines laid
out ready to fly. It is probably taken some

1696.78.text: time during the lunch period of early afternoon.

1702.15.text:
Here are some of the men waiting to board
the second wave - the Dakota C47s flying in.

1710.52.text:
And it is rather touching, in the Imperial
War Museum, in one of the photo albums,

1716.03.text:
there is a little note attached to this photograph
and the chap in the foreground on the left...

1721.66.text:
the note says, 'This is my grandad,' which
is rather nice note and identifies him.

1728.05.text:
So they're waiting to emplane, and that included
the mules. The standing instruction was

1735.63.text:
if any of the mules give you trouble you shoot them, 
OK. But most of them were actually good passengers.

1740.40.text:
But, of course, it was rather difficult persuading 
them to board; it wasn't an orderly process.

1744.90.text:
But sadly one of the men I interviewed, his first task 
on landing was to shoot the mule

1755.48.text:
that broke one of its front legs during 
heavy landing and getting very excited.

1765.99.text:
There was a problem flying in. There was a
last minute reconnaissance -

1770.65.text:
I don't have time to give you all the information, 
but basically it looked as though one of the clearings

1777.14.text:
had been basically obstructed deliberately
with the use of teak logs. In fact, the teak logs

1785.34.text:
had just been left to dry in the sun
by some of the local village people,

1791.49.text:
but it didn't seem that way looking at the aerial
photographs. And it was decided to fly everybody

1796.44.text:
in to Broadway. In fact, the take-off of the
first glider train was only just under an

1805.01.text:
hour delayed because they had to reconfigure the lift 
and do a lot of things at the very last minute.

1811.22.text:
But it was less than an hour,
the delay, which was quite an achievement.

1819.21.text:
Here we are - glider under tow. Most of the
tows were dual tows and that meant a lot of

1823.89.text:
the gliders were lost. Over 30 of the gliders
were actually lost. Some of them came down

1830.31.text:
on the right side of the Chindwin River. A
lot of them came down on the wrong side of

1834.80.text:
the river and some crashed during the night
landing.

1839.57.text:
You can see here that No 1 Air Commando, Colonel
Cochran's Chindit air force, was supposed

1848.35.text:
to be a secret organisation. So you can see
what the logo was for this secret squadron -

1857.52.text:
A lot of the gliders, when they landed, crashed.
I met a man who experienced a crash like this.

1869.24.text:
His name is Frank Anderson and he was a Vickers
gunner and his glider landed in a lake,

1876.27.text:
not too far from the airfield they had taken off
from. It started yawing and pitching and uncontrollable

1881.97.text:
so the pilot had no choice but to release.
And he ended up with a Vickers gun on top

1887.57.text:
of him in a flooded fuselage of the glider.
Fortunately his mates managed to pull him out.

1894.34.text:
He is 95 next birthday and he is still
young and cheeky as far as I'm concerned.

1902.43.text:
So, this is the day after. This is Monday,
6 March 1944, on the airfield. You can see

1910.88.text:
there are two gliders there locked together.
The idea was that if gliders crashed you would

1915.24.text:
move them off but you couldn't move them off
because of the huge ruts in the grounds caused

1919.54.text:
by the dragging of teak logs by elephant teams.
So they were basically stuck there.

1925.81.text:
And a lot of the gliders crashed on the runway.
In fact, two or three of them went into the

1930.94.text:
trees and they couldn't get the bodies out
so they cremated them on the spot,

1936.72.text: it was the only way of dealing with it.

1940.80.text:
The gentleman on the far left there, with
his hands on his hips watching his men work,

1946.69.text:
his name is Peter Hepple. He's still alive
and he's still very fit for his age.

1953.41.text:
And he's told them that they get no tea until 
they've done their stretch of the airstrip.

1959.06.text:
So they're working there in the hot Burmese sun. 
You can see the mini bulldozer that was

1967.69.text:
Not every Dakota got away with it. Here you
can see one that crashed into a paddy bund

1974.08.text:
with rather devastating consequences. But
once they were down they could give the signal.

1981.92.text:
There was some initial hesitation; they gave
a signal that indicated that the landings

1987.25.text:
had not been successful. But, with the arrival
of daylight and the ability to more fully

1993.75.text:
assess the situation, it was decided that they 
were in fact a success and the signal was sent.

2002.52.text:
I like this photograph; I think it's timeless.
It's a Chindit patrol walking through a village

2009.41.text:
and one of the soldiers has caught the eye
of one of the village maidens,

2014.61.text: which is, I think, rather nice.

2017.32.text:
Wingate visited his battalion commanders and
his brigade commanders in the field.

2028.92.text:
And, unfortunately, three weeks into Operation
THURSDAY, he was killed in an air crash heading

2034.99.text:
back to India for conference. And he crashed
into a hillside. He had two war correspondents

2042.19.text:
with him and a five-man American crew. There
are lots of theories about why this crash

2049.83.text:
happened and you pays your money and takes
your choice. I actually came across a source

2058.86.text:
for a third theory - I don't have time to
explain it today.

2062.68.text:
But there was an agreement between the Americans
and the British that in crashes where basically

2070.24.text:
you couldn't sort out the bits and pieces,
the majority would lead you to where the remains

2077.13.text:
would be interred. And that's why Major General
Orde Wingate is actually buried at Arlington Cemetery.

2083.34.text:
He moved around a bit before then,
but that is where his remains are now

2088.85.text: with those who died with him.

2091.49.text:
There is 22 Column of the Queen's on patrol.
This is quite open country and we will see

2098.78.text:
some examples of more typical jungle a little
later on.

2104.20.text:
This is General Lentaigne, who was Wingate's
successor, a Gurkha officer.

2112.78.text:
He apparently was no great fan of Wingate and no great fan 
of the Chindits - didn't like irregular warfare at all.

2117.58.text:
And there were some questions about
his qualities in the field as a brigade commander.

2124.61.text:
His officers were beginning to lose confidence
in him, but nevertheless he got the job of

2129.44.text:
taking over the Chindits at a point when they
were just about to be handed over to the command

2135.86.text:
of General Stilwell, 'Vinegar Joe' Stilwell,
the American general in charge of the Chinese troops

2143.27.text:
in northern Burma. And he was very
definitely an Anglo-phobe. And over 90 per cent

2149.72.text:
of Chindit casualties in the second campaign
came after that handover to General Stilwell's command.

2159.06.text:
And the consequences, of course,
remain with many families to this day.

2169.93.text:
These were young men - the youngest Chindit
that I've been able to find was just 18 -

2177.37.text:
and most of them were in their early 20s. My dad
was a fairly old Chindit; he was about 26 when he went in.

2182.15.text:
The ones who were over 21
tended to be the best stayers, actually,

2190.27.text:
in this very arduous campaign. Nobody over 40
was allowed to go in; it was thought to be

2196.85.text: simply too much of a physical challenge.

2201.82.text:
A place was set up blocking the road and railway
running north-south and supplying the Japanese army

2207.91.text:
in northern Burma, and the block was
called White City. It was basically a defended

2214.63.text:
square straddling the road and railway at
a relatively favourable point. And to give

2222.26.text:
you some idea, the barbed wire defences were
30-40 yards [27-36m] thick, or wide, and the

2230.66.text:
Japanese tried desperately to break into that
stronghold over a seven-week period.

2236.92.text:
At the end there were 1,200 Japanese bodies
on the wire and nobody could do anything with them.

2241.99.text:
They tried to use flame throwers on them at one 
point, but that just changed one smell for another.

2248.63.text:
And they also asked for quick lime to be dropped, 
but there was nothing you could do.

2255.91.text:
You couldn't bury them - it was far too dangerous - 
so they stayed on the wire.

2260.10.text:
And if you look at the expression
of the man on the right, it gives you some

2263.79.text:
idea of what seven weeks of fighting at White City 
must have felt like. It was called White City,

2269.96.text:
incidentally, because the forest around
the perimeter was festooned with white parachutes

2279.54.text:
from the supply drops and that is how it has
got its name - White City.

2284.88.text:
Meanwhile, Broadway - the main base for flying
in reinforcements and flying in heavy stores -

2292.97.text:
had to be defended against a number of Japanese
ground attacks. These men were involved in

2298.03.text:
a bayonet charge to clear the Japanese from
one end of the airstrip and I've managed to

2306.24.text:
identify correctly - this photograph was often
identified incorrectly, but I know who these

2312.74.text:
men are because I found a Chindit veteran
who was friends with the man on the left,

2318.98.text:
the man carrying two rifles, he's a sergeant,
and I've managed to identify even the person

2326.33.text:
on the stretcher. So he's being carried back
to a clearing for casualty evacuation.

2336.73.text:
But things were not straight forward flying in
heavy aircraft, relatively heavy aircraft

2342.42.text:
into rough jungle strips. So, not an easy
thing to do.

2350.56.text:
My dad's battalion had two elephants and they
were used to carry three-inch mortar rounds.

2357.27.text:
And the mahouts - you can see them on the
elephants - they wouldn't work for money,

2362.80.text:
they only worked for opium. So one of QQ requests
for supplies to be dropped included a request

2370.01.text:
for a brick of opium. And they'd go for about
three days on a piece of opium

2374.96.text: the size of your thumbnail. So, there we are.

2380.31.text:
I also managed to interview a 'kicker'. 
You can see the man on the left has got his back

2385.19.text:
to the fuselage rigs and he is kicking out and 
the guys are on either side are dropping the stores.

2395.71.text:
And here's a Chindit column in action, basically
getting ready to blow a railway bridge.

2406.49.text:
It's not much of a thing, a Burmese railway bridge,
but that is what they are doing. The two charges

2412.16.text:
that they're laying immediately are called
'hasty charges' because if they're disturbed

2417.20.text:
in the act of rigging the bridge for blowing,
then at least they can cut the railway line

2421.64.text:
instantly as they beat a hasty retreat.
I used to have a standing joke with my father,

2428.74.text:
I used to say to him, 'You spent five months
helping to blow up railway lines, and then

2433.33.text:
you spend the next 40 years with British Rail
repairing them.' He was a welder on the tracks.

2440.70.text:
This is Chindit cuisine. You can see the way
to do your cooking there is to take two pieces

2447.96.text:
of wood, put some kindling underneath, put
your mess tin there and then basically put

2453.16.text:
in whatever you've got. And there were some
very strange concoctions.

2461.36.text: One favourite word for this mess was called 'burgoo'.

2464.61.text:
I was fascinated when I was a kid, I used
to watch my dad eating his dinner and he would

2468.40.text:
reach a certain point and when he got half
way through he used to mash up everything

2472.61.text:
on his plate and shape it into, like, a rectangular
brick and then eat it from there. And it's

2478.41.text:
only now that I realise that it was probably
just about the size of a mess tin,

2483.48.text:
so maybe the habit stayed with him longer than one
might expect, I don't know.

2488.10.text:
This is the aftermath of the supply drop.
The chap walking away has got a big box of K rations.

2494.35.text:
And here's a distribution point, so you would 
come forward platoon by platoon to get your supplies.

2503.21.text:
Here's a commando platoon waiting to put in
an attack,

2512.60.text:
and you get some idea of the country 
that they're operating in.

2513.74.text:
Here, there's a blown bridge, and there is
somebody out there looking for trouble.

2521.68.text:
This is quite amusing. This is Lieutenant
Colonel Graves-Morris of the York and Lancaster Regiment.

2527.38.text:
It's his 30th birthday. His sergeant
major has been carrying for several hundred

2534.27.text:
miles the only bottle of beer in north Burma
and he has decided to give it to Graves-Morris

2541.50.text:
for his 30th birthday, which is why he looks so delighted 
and completely amazed at what is happening.

2549.78.text:
Graves-Morris was court martialled after the
war. Two of his men were flogged -

2557.60.text:
one for being asleep on sentry duty and the other
one for stealing rations. My dad, in his column,

2562.96.text:
also saw two men flogged for stealing rations.
And the problem was what sort of punishment

2570.66.text:
can you give men in that situation? I mean
you can't confine them to barracks, for example.

2576.73.text:
You could stop their pay, but it's meaningless.
What can you do in that situation?

2581.18.text:
So, most men in that situation were given
the choice of accepting, themselves, a flogging.

2587.80.text:
And it was usually done by a cat o' nine tails
made out of parachute cord. And one of the

2594.29.text:
men flogged in... I think it was 65 Column,
when he got home he mentioned this to his

2601.15.text:
family and one of the family objected and
mentioned it to the local MP.

2605.74.text:
Questions were asked in the House [of Commons] and 
before you knew it Graves-Morris was court martialled.

2610.25.text:
He was exonerated, and he was exonerated on
the basis that one day's service in the

2615.56.text: Chindit column was far worse than being flogged.

2621.50.text:
This is where my father nearly lost his life.
It doesn't look much. It's basically a place called Blackpool.

2627.21.text:
When White City was abandoned,
the Chindit force moved north but they still

2633.84.text:
had the job of blocking that road and railway.
And they chose a new block site called Blackpool.

2639.39.text:
But it wasn't a successful as White City.
It was too close to the main Japanese force

2646.24.text:
in northern Burma. They could bring up artillery
and basically in just under three weeks

2656.20.text:
There were 2,000 men inside, including this lot. The tall 
man there came very, very close to being left.

2663.82.text:
He found himself in a position
where he couldn't march. He had dysentery

2669.61.text:
and he had malaria and he couldn't march any
longer. And his officer, it's a reconnaissance platoon,

2675.51.text:
his officer gave him an intravenous
shot of quinine and within 20 minutes

2680.45.text: he could walk again. He saved his life.

2686.26.text:
They flew in a battery of 25-pounder guns.
Some of you may have seen this type of gun -

2693.03.text:
I think they were 25 pounders outside [the
National Army Museum]. They were broken down

2697.85.text:
and loaded into Dakotas, flown into Blackpool,
reassembled and I will show you the shoot

2704.64.text:
plan in a second. The chap who was in charge
of the guns at Blackpool went back 60-odd years later

2711.62.text:
and found his command post, which
was really quite remarkable.

2719.14.text:
And his son who does things with computers 
basically generated this image.

2724.17.text:
Here's a shoot plan for U Troop for, I think,
the 160th Jungle Field Regiment. And they're

2736.03.text:
basically firing on the railway, firing on
lorries that are on the road and supporting

2743.67.text:
troops floating outside the block and taking
on the Japanese if they come under pressure

2749.71.text:
giving them fire support. And he drew this
up from memory and a few notes this chap -

2756.78.text:
But the problem was the Japanese brought up
anti-aircraft guns and with anti-aircraft guns

2761.27.text:
around the perimeter you can't fly in supplies. 
The last drop involved 12 C47s, 12 Dakotas.

2769.53.text:
Eleven of them were hit and three
of them went in flying at 500 feet [152m].

2777.07.text:
And that was it. Basically they ran out of
food, but they weren't worried about the food,

2784.19.text:
they were running out of ammunition. And when
the block was actually overrun they only had

2788.93.text:
12 rounds of ammunition left. So, there was
no question about it, the block had to go.

2794.20.text:
It was basically penetrated feature by feature
and gradually was overrun.

2800.79.text:
And there was the problem with the wounded.
There were 2,000 men inside the block and

2806.60.text:
they had been firing up to 600 shells a day
into a relatively small area. And most of

2813.11.text:
the casualties were from shrapnel and some
of them couldn't be moved. So when they started

2819.74.text:
to move out of the block - and they were very
fortunate because although the Japanese surrounded

2823.76.text:
it they left a gap, and the gap led to a track,
and it was a track up a 3,000 foot [914m]

2830.57.text:
high hill and 2,000 men went, Indian file,
up that hill and lived... with, obviously,

2840.88.text:
But there were 18 men who couldn't be moved,
they were too badly injured. And it was decided

2847.56.text:
that they wouldn't be left to the mercy of
the Japanese and they were shot. And the medical

2852.44.text:
officer pointed out to [John] Masters, who
was in charge of 111 Brigade in the block,

2860.59.text:
he said, 'We don't have enough morphine for
all of them.'

2865.63.text:
So, he said, 
'Give it to the ones whose eyes are open.'

2868.54.text:
But those who did escape marched up that trail
for three or four days, reached an assembly point

2877.84.text:
and then went down into the Indawgyi
Lake where two Sunderland flying boats,

2884.91.text:
'Gert' and 'Daisy', flew 500 of them to safety. And
others made their way by river on the Chindit Navy,

2894.87.text:
which were huge rafts that were built
to evacuate the men.

2900.78.text:
This chap is still alive. I was hoping he
would be here today. He can't be here because

2905.21.text:
at the age of 92 he still does one day a week
in the City of London. He's an accountant... [Laughter]

2909.94.text:
and the auditors are in today and
he can't be here. But I was hoping he'd be here

2916.03.text:
with me today. He was flown out because
he had an abscess, but it was an abscess the

2920.65.text:
size of a small apple in the small of his
back right where the bottom on the pack rested.

2926.51.text:
And basically he couldn't march with his kit
because of it and he was also basically in

2931.78.text:
an advanced state of blood poisoning. So,
they evacuated him and this picture was taken

2935.87.text:
ten minutes after the abscess was lanced.
Despite the ineffectual anaesthetic you can

2941.79.text: see he was highly delighted with the result.

2944.75.text:
Meanwhile, the Chindits were misused as assault
troops by Stilwell. And Lentaigne, unfortunately,

2954.18.text:
went along with it. And here you see them
assaulting the village or the town of Mogaung -

2959.84.text:
let's call it a town, it's not really a
town as you and I understand it.

2965.58.text:
It's a mortar team in action and you can see here 
that they've blown a bridge and they are keeping it

2971.48.text: under observation on the outskirts of the town.

2973.88.text:
This is the only brick building in Mogaung
and here on your left is Michael Calvert,

2980.85.text:
perhaps the ultimate Chindit fighting commander.
And you will see that he has got a rifle,

2988.68.text:
and the reason for that is you don't want to identify 
yourself as an officer in situations like this.

2993.49.text:
On the right-hand side is Major Lumley, 
Joanna Lumley's father. It's an interesting

3003.01.text:
photograph that, Major Lumley...it almost
looks as though he could be in Vietnam.

3011.16.text:
This is 'General' Lee. He's not really a general,
he's an NCO [non-commissioned officer] and

3017.98.text:
after the attack you can see him resting in
bivouac.

3021.92.text: You can also see that his weapons are fairly close by.

3025.39.text:
This chap was the oldest Chindit in one of
the columns. He is 39 years old and you can

3031.76.text:
see from his ribs that they've been on a prolonged
period of K rations. When the Chindits came out,

3038.35.text:
back at base somebody came in with a
box of K rations and two Chindits looked at

3044.34.text:
it and immediately vomited. That will give
you some idea of how much they hated them at the end.

3052.55.text:
This photograph, I will just show you, because
it has a very amusing caption. On the back of it

3057.34.text:
it says, 'Stinky gets his boil lanced.'
And I asked the man who took the photograph

3064.24.text:
about it and he said that it seemed very funny
at the time.

3067.84.text:
These are the European officers surviving from 
two Chindit columns, West African Chindit columns,

3078.47.text:
after an assault on a feature called
'Hill 60'. And these are the survivors -

3088.92.text:
This is a chap waiting to be flown out. He's
lost his bush hat and he's got his small pack

3093.80.text:
on to protect his head. Many of them stayed
in Changi jail and weren't liberated until

3102.74.text:
the following year, many Chindit prisoners,
including the chap sitting down to the very right.

3109.23.text:
I interviewed him - he's suffering
from beriberi in the picture.

3113.26.text:
The Japanese surrendered in Burma. That's General Wavell 
with a Chindit RSM [regimental sergeant major]

3120.46.text:
who had a reputation of being
a very tough RSM. Apparently his nickname

3125.88.text:
was 'kitna', and 'kitna' is Urdu for 'too
much'. He looks too much.

3130.74.text:
That's the photograph my dad sent back after
he got out... and some Christmas greetings.

3137.63.text:
Back in Changi jail, this man had his leg
amputated without anaesthetic, and survived.

3143.96.text:
This is a chap who was in charge of the guns at Blackpool; 
he lost an eye getting up that 3,000 foot [914m] track.

3153.02.text:
This chap didn't come back. He's reading a copy of 
'Life' magazine dropped in one of the air drops.

3161.73.text:
Other Chindit veterans. And this is 64 Chindit
veterans at the laying up of the standard in 2009

3167.76.text:
in Litchfield Cathedral with their
patron, The Prince of Wales.

3173.56.text:
And that's it ladies and gentleman. 
Thank you very much.
